Jake LaMotta.Action: Engages the audience warmly with humor and self-deprecation during a nightclub monologue.
Shadow-boxes and keeps his footwork and punching style sharp despite being out of shape and overweight at 42.
Rehearses a nightclub monologue confidently, showing poise in a new role outside boxing.
Acknowledges the physical toll of his boxing career humorously but realistically.
Persistently staggers forward under attack, showing determination and resilience, despite being battered.
Takes water and spits blood into the bucket his younger brother Joey holds, showing reliance and trust in his brother's support.
Charges at Reeves desperately in the last round, demonstrating fighting spirit but not necessarily warmth.
Despite being battered and outpointed, he pulls himself up and charges at his opponent with a desperate and ferocious attack, ultimately knocking him down.
Engages in a reckless, wild alley-fighting attack rather than a calculated, skillful approach.
Dances around the ring, kisses his gloves, and thrusts them toward the crowd after the fight.
Prances around stunned and raises arms in victory despite the official decision against him.
Dances around the ring, kissing his gloves and thrusting them toward the crowd after a controversial decision loss, showing confidence and resilience despite the outcome.

Is stunned and tries to figure out what happened after losing the fight despite clearly knocking his opponent down and nearly achieving a knockout, indicating some confusion or lack of control over the situation.
Sits quietly at the kitchen table while his wife cooks, making a mild comment about the food.
Sits bandaged from a recent fight, has had a few glasses of wine, pokes at food in a distracted or possibly careless manner.
Insists on eating the steak his way despite Irma's attempts to serve it properly; displays impatience and stubbornness.
Insists on eating the steak even though it is undercooked, prioritizing impatience over carefulness.

Reflects on his victory and acknowledges a mistake (should have knocked out Reeves earlier), showing self-awareness and strategic thinking about fights.
Sits drinking with tears on his face, privately shares his insecurities with Joey.
